Adolfo lives and works in Ica, Peru. Ica is located in the Sechura Desert about four hours south of Lima, the country's capital, and is hailed by Peruvians as "The Land of the Sun." It is known in Peru for its frequent earthquakes (an 8.4 in 2001 and 8.0 in 2007), its production of grapes, asparagus, and olives, and perhaps most notably, as the source of Peruvian's traditional national drink, Pisco. In this hot, arid climate we find the client's home and business.

loans.use: to pay for the general maintenance of his car.

loans.name: Rhubie

texts.en:
Rhubie is from the village of Clarin. She is 39 years old. Rhubie is married. To make a living, Rhubie owns & operates a "sari-sari" (general store) business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Rhubie has been engaged in her business for over 8 year and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month from these activities.


In 2004, Rhubie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rhubie has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Rhubie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more stocks to sell. This loan will be the 26th loan taken out by Rhubie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell

loans.name: Chim

texts.en:
Mrs. Chim is a 33-year-old married woman who has been living in Kompong Speu province, Cambodia. She is a mother of five unmarried children who depend on her income. Most of them are enrolled in a local public school. She is dedicated to agriculture for her livelihood and for support of her family. 

At present, Mrs. Chim needs some funds to complete house building. As shown in the photo, she is standing next to the structure of her house.  She will use this loan to cover her house with thatch, especially the roof and wall. She hopes to get this loan and is very thankful to all lenders in advance.

loans.use: to cover her house with thatch, especially the roof and walls.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is 56 years old, married with 4 children. Leonora is from Kinuman, Ozamis city. Her husband is a farmer.
The family has a meager income, that's why Leonora decided to establish a small food stall. 

Leonora is in food business selling bread "puto maya, suman and coffee" in the market. She has been in this business for 3 years and earns 2,500PHP a month. Leonora 

In 2009, Leonora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. 

Leonora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Leonora is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase ingredients for "suman and puto maya" glutinous rice . This loan will be her second cycle from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: purchase ingredients for "suman and puto maya" glutinous rice

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 59 years-old and a widow with two children. She's from Poblacion 4, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. 

Teresita owns and operate farm land, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Teresita has been farming for ten years and she earn 18,000 PHP a month. 

In 2008, Teresita joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and pay for labor. This will be the 14th loan taken out by Teresita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pay for labor.

loans.name: Rowelyn

texts.en:
Rowelyn is from Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years-old. Rowelyn is married and has three children. 

To make a living, Rowelyn is running a general store, selling a variety of food and home use products in the local community such as candies, shampoo, soaps and many other items. Rowelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Rowelyn is requesting a loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offerings. In 2010, Rowelyn joined Kiva partner GDMPC in order to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to expand and improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offerings.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy speakers (for music)

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny is a married woman with four children. She is 35 years old and resides in Lusot, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental: Philippines. 

Jenny owns and operate a farm, planting and harvesting rice for sale to earn a living. She's been in this business for 3 years. Each month, she earns 3,000 PHP doing this type of business. 

She requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Jenny has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, she wants to make improvements to her house and improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Uini

texts.en:
Uini is 36 years of age, married, and has 4 children.  She owns & operates a business venture selling baked goods in the local community.  She has 4 years of experience in this business.  She needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells.  She plans to use the profits from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve and expand it.

In 2011, Uini joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Uini's 1st loan with SPBD.



*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells

loans.name: Faifua

texts.en:
Faifua is 36 years of age, married, and has 4 children.  She owns & operates a business venture planting & harvesting bananas for sale.  She has 3 years of experience in this business.  She needs a loan of WST $2000.00 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the profits from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve and expand it.

In 2006, Faifau joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Faifua's 5th loan with SPBD.


*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio is married with two children. He is 38 years old and resides in Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur: Philippines.

Rogelio operates a fishing business selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community to earn a living. He has been in this business for 1 year. Each month, he earns 10,000 PHP doing this type of business.

He requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. Rogelio has been a member of GDMPC for 2 years. In the future, Rogelio wants to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets.

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Elizabeth Marlene

texts.es:
Elizabeth  vive y trabaja en famous Nazca, or Nasca, Perú. The city is well known for the legendary Nazca Lines- a series of ancient, immense and inexplicable geoglyphs etched into the desert surrounding the city, generally attributed to the Nazca culture, which inhabited in the region from 300-800 AD. As such, the city attracts a considerable amount of tourism. But Nazca is also known for its hardworking people, who have preserved despite frequent earthquakes, tsunamis, and a high level of poverty in the region.
Elizabeth es una mujer separada, tiene un  hijo de 15 años el cual esta cursando el nivel secundario, ella se dedica a la venta de gaseosas y recargas virtuales movistar, empezó con un pequeño capital que su tío le otorgo.  Elizabeth es una  mujer trabajadora y muy empeñosa con muchas ganas de sacar a delante  a su hijo, empezó en el negocio hace 5 años y gana un promedio de S/. 200.00 soles semanales.
Con el crédito que le otorgará Kiva de S/. 1000.00 soles lo invertirá para la compra de tarjetas virtuales ( claro y movistar),  para que de esta manera pueda tener mas ingresos para poderle dar una mejor calidad de vida a su hijo, uno de sus sueños es tener su propia casa y que su hijo llegue  a ser un gran profesional, su asesor cree que es un buen cliente y que va a pagar puntualmente sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Elizabeth lives and works in the famous Nazca, or Nasca, Perú. The city is well known for the legendary Nazca Lines- a series of ancient, immense and inexplicable geoglyphs etched into the desert surrounding the city, generally attributed to the Nazca culture, which inhabited the region from 300-800 AD. As such, the city attracts a considerable amount of tourism. However, Nazca is also known for its hardworking people, who have persevered despite frequent earthquakes, tsunamis, and a high level of poverty in the region.

Elizabeth is separated and has a 15-year-old son who is in secondary school. She makes a living selling soft drinks and virtual Movistar [a local cellular service company] cell phone credits. She started with a small amount of capital that her uncle gave her. Elizabeth is a hardworking and diligent woman with a great desire to help her son get ahead. She started the business five years ago and makes an average of 200 PEN a week.

With the 1,000 PEN loan from Kiva she will invest in the purchase of virtual cell phone credits (Claro and Movistar [local cellular service companies]). In this way she will have more income to be able to give her son a better quality of life. One of her dreams is to have her own house and that her son will become a great professional. Her loan advisor believes that she is a good client and that she will make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to purchase virtual cell phone credits (Movistar and Claro).

loans.name: Faaseseina

texts.en:
Faaseseina is 34 years old and married with 4 children.  She owns & operates a business venture selling baked goods in the local community.  She has 2 years of experience in this business.    She needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells.  She plans to use the profits from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve and expand it.

In 2010, Faaseseina joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Faaseseina's 3rd loan with SPBD.

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

loans.name: Maikeronisia

texts.en:
Maikeronisia is 43 years old and married with 6 children.  She owns & operates a business venture planting & harvesting taro for sale.  She has 3 years of experience in this business. She needs a loan of WST $2000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the profits from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to pay for her children's tuition fees.

In 2006, Maikeronisia joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Maikeronisia's 5th loan with SPBD.

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Conception

texts.en:
This is Conception, 55, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. Her husband is Rolando, a vendor. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Conception maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customers order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 2000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, Conception is requesting a PHP23,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy merchandise and to fill the orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Conception hopes to grow her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for inventory items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Khin

texts.en:
Khin is 26 years old. She has spent most of her life cultivating rice crops from the Kompong Speu province. Presently, she lives with a small child while her husband is working away from home as a driver. She is a good housewife who manages everything in her house; she is tidy and looks after her children carefully. 

With the loan she has requested from HKL and Kiva, she wants to buy two calves for raising and keep them for farming work after they grow big enough.  Her business goal is to expand her farming business: she intends to start growing rice crops both in the rainy season and in the dry season. Furthermore, she wants to increase her income through a cow-breeding business in the coming years.

loans.use: to buy two calves for raising and keep them for farming work after they grow big enough.

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Chanthy is 33 years old and her husband, Tork, is 37 years old. They live in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have one son and two daughters who are in school. 
 

Chanthy is a weaver and raises pigs at home, while her husband sells piglets. He buys piglets from the fellow villagers and sells in other districts. 

Chanthy is asking for her first loan in the amount of $400 to purchase additional piglets for her husband to sell.   

Photo: Chanthy is pictured next to her pigpen.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets for her husband to sell

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
This is Susana, 45, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Reynaldo, her business partner. She and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Susana operates a rolling store. Her rolling store is basically a small housewares store, which retails plastic containers, dippers, pails, plastic flowers and basins to the local neighborhood. Her husband drives the rolling store within the local community to sell the products. She earns her income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP700 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy pails, plastic ware, hangers, clothes pins, plastic flowers and rags to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Susana dreams to be able to grow her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock of plastic wares she needs in her business.

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Chantha (pictured with her young son) is 30 years old and her husband is 32 year old. They live about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2002 and have two young children, one son and one daughter.  
Chantha and her husband are fish sellers. She is asking for her first loan in the mount of $500 to expand her business by purchasing additional fish for sale.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish for sale.

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en:
This is Hazel, 40, a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Remegio, an electrician, and father of her four children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.
  
Hazel operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. 

Hazel earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Hazel dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week; there she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Son

texts.en:
Son (in the photo), age 53, lives in a village about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She is a widow with two sons and three daughters. One is married and lives in a separate home, one is a garment worker, one is a security guard, another one stays at home, and another one attends school.  

Son is a babysitter. She is applying for her first loan in the amount of $200 to purchase additional motorbike spare parts for her son-in-law’s motorbike repairing business.

loans.use: To purchase additional motorbike spare parts for her son-in-law’s motorbike repairing business.

loans.name: Sammot

texts.en:
Sammot is 39 years old and her husband, Yorn, is 51 years old. They live in a village about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1990 and have two sons and one daughter. One is a lathe operator, another one is a gardener, and another one is in school.    

Sammot sells vegetables and fish. She buys vegetables and fish from the market and brings them on her bicycle to sell in her village. Her husband is a farmer and raises cows at home. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase one more cow for her husband to raise.

loans.use: To purchase one more cow for her husband to raise.

loans.name: Aotoa

texts.en:
Aotoa is 53 years old, married, and has six children.

She owns and operates a business venture, planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale.  She has two years of experience in this business.   Aotoa needs a loan of WST $1,000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand her business.

In 2009, Aotoa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Because they lack collateral, most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks. This is Aotoa's second loan with SPBD. 

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.

loans.name: Haide

texts.en:
This is Haide, 35, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Glenn, a businessman. She is the mother of three children; all of them are still studying in elementary school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college, which is a dream for most Filipino parents like Haide as she herself is a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Haide operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from those round palm sized ones, to the much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers come up with every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 215 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread, and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Haide dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 
 
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Fetu

texts.en:
Fetu is 30 years old and married with 3 children.

Fetu is starting a business venture selling fried foods in the local community. She needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2011, Fetu joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Fetu's first loan with SPBD. 

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive, and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Yan

texts.en:
Yan lives in a village about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She is a widow with one son who is married and is an English teacher and one daughter who is in school.

Yan sells Cambodian cakes in her village. She makes the cakes by herself. Yan is asking for her first loan in the amount of $300 to buy a computer for her daughter who is in school. 

Photo: Yan is pictured with her grandson.

loans.use: To purchase a computer for her daughter.

loans.name: Tuavao

texts.en:
Tuavao is 48 years old and married with 5 children.

Tuavao owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting taro for sale. She has many years of experience in this business. Tuavao needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchase weed killers, such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 550 talas or US $229 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2011, Tuavao joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Tuavao's first loan with SPBD. 

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score." loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
This is Norma, 55, resident of Dasmariñas Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Evilio, a carpenter, and is the mother of three children. One is already working while the other two are married. By the grace of God, Norma has managed to support their daily needs.

Norma operates a tailoring business. She’s been in this business for 25 years. She mainly offers curtains, bed sheets, blankets, and other home draping. Seasonal demands for clothing like uniforms and such are available all year round. She also does repairs and alterations. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php700 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Norma dreams to build a tailoring shop and to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.
 
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Mrs. Cheng, 32, is a humble farmer who has been residing in Baray district. She lives there with her 2 school-aged children and grows annual rice crops. In order to make more income, Cheng sells many types of vegetable throughout the village from her bicycle, from which she is able to earn approximately $2 per day. Mrs. Cheng wants to reach other communes to increase selling her vegetables, but she can’t arrive there by cycling her bike. It will take a lot of time and won’t be on time to satisfy the customer’s needs. For this reason, Mrs. Cheng is requesting a loan from Kiva, through HKL to purchase a used motorcycle for transporting her vegetables to the marketplace. She hopes that she will be able to generate additional income for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a used motorcycle for transporting her vegetables to the marketplace.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
This is Juliana, 46, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Pedro, a security guard.  At this time, she is working hard to be able to support their daily expenses.

Juliana operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from round palm sized ones to the much larger doormats, braided quilts, bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers come up with every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, they are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread, and other materials. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Juliana hopes to grow her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and she also draws strength and inspiration from the word of God.
 
* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Sivaimamao

texts.en:
Sivaimamao is 22 years of age and married.

Sivaimamao owns & operates a business venture, selling baked goods in the local community.  She has 1 year of experience in this business.    Sivaimamao needs a loan of WST 1000 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2011, Sivaimamao joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Sivaimamao's 1st loan with SPBD. 



*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  "

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rodel

texts.en: Rodel is 24 years old, married, and blessed with one child. He supports his family through his farming business. He plants and harvests corn and sells to dealers to receive funds for his family. His willingness to lift his family out of poverty makes him want to dedicate his full time to monitoring his farming business. He wants to increase his income, amounting to P25,000 last month, to save for the growth of his family as well as to their future. Rodel is now asking for a loan in the amount of P20,000 to buy corn seeds, pesticides, and fertilizers for his farm. He hopes to maintain his business through this loan in order to secure his family financially.

loans.use: to buy corn seeds, pesticides, and fertilizers for his farm

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
This is Maribeth, 28, resident of Dasmarinas Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Rodelito, a seaman, and is the mother of three children, two of whom are in grade school. She, together with her children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income to cover her everyday expenses.  

Maribeth operates a buy-and-sell business. What she basically does is buy beauty products merchandise from wholesalers, sell them by the piece with a profit. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of beauty products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Maribeth dreams to be able to give all her children a high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also dreams to have her own shop in a commercial place. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 
 
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of items and beauty products needed in her business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a farmer working in Trinidad, Bohol. She is 29 years old, married with 3 children.

Marilyn work with her husband in their farm. They primarily grow rice crops to sell. Marilyn works hard to improve their harvest and earnings. She requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. Marilyn hopes to earn more and to be able to save for her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
This is Rowena, 42, resident of Dasmariñas Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Wilson, a landscape artist, and is the mother to their six children, five of whom are still studying. She is working hard to send all her children to college, because like most Filipino parents she believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can give their children.

Rowena operates a landscaping business. Together with her husband, she offers landscaping services to those who would like to improve their homes or gardens. She also supplies ornamentals plants and other materials for landscaping to those people who do landscaping as a hobby. She earns a minimum of Php 1500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is applying for a loan of Php50,000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more landscaping materials needed in her business. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Rowena dreams of having a new outlet for the expansion of their business and hopes to send all her children to college. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for landscaping materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Randoll Harrison

texts.es: El señor Randoll es un joven de 21 años de edad a quien le gusta cantar música hip hop e integra esta actividad con su propio puesto a la salida de un colegio en el cual vende todo tipo de variedades tales como accesorios femeninos, papelería, entre otros artículos. El señor Randoll desea salir adelante y emprender sus estudios de música, para lo cual requiere de la compra de mercancía que le permita surtir su negocio para la temporada de fin de año y de esta manera además poder aumentar sus ventas, mejorar su calidad de vida y alcanzar su sueño de ser un gran cantante y tener su propio almacén de variedades.
texts.en: Sr. Randoll is a young man who is 21 years of age and likes to sing hip hop music while he manages his own vending post outside of a school where he sells all types of merchandise such as women’s accessories, stationery, and other items.  He wants to succeed and begin his music studies, but he needs to buy merchandise so that he can restock his business for the year-end season in order to increase his sales, improve his quality of life, and pursue his dream of becoming a famous singer.  Randoll also wants to own a variety store.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell during the year-end season.

loans.name: Merilyn

texts.en:
Merilyn is a married woman who has 5 children. The oldest child is 16 years old. Merilyn has been engaged in farming for 10 years. She tills land in her town in Trinidad, Bohol. Merilyn grows rice to sell. She earns 8000 PHP per month doing this farming.

Merilyn has requested a loan to purchase fertilizers, certified seeds and other farm inputs. Merilyn hopes for her business to grow. She also desires to see her children finish college and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, certified seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
This is Vilma, 53, resident of Dasmariñas Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Danilo, a contractor, and mother of four children. Three of her children are already working and have their own families, while the youngest is still in high school. Vilma and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Vilma operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs: from those round palm sized ones, to the much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers produce every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. She also sells cooked meats for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP850 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP9,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials.  She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Vilma dreams to be able to give her all of her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies. 
 
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
This is Grace, 47, a resident of Dasmariñas Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Mariano, a local official, and mother to their two children. She and her husband and children manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Grace operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighbourhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP700 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP11,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Grace hopes to be able to expand her business soon, just as she hopes to send all of her children to college. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rice seeds for growing during this season and to pay for housing repair.

loans.name: Binh

texts.en:
Binh is 36 years old. She has three children. One of them was married. Her main job is farming. She not only grows rice and raises poultry, but also she makes rice noodles to sell. She has had this job for three years. She has a monthly income of about 4,500,000 Vietnamese dong (VND).

She has participated in SEDA since 2008. She is a member of the Duc Lan cluster. The last time she borrowed 7,392,000 VND and repaid this loan punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,184,000 VND to buy rice to make noodles and buy food for poultry.

loans.use: to buy rice to make noodles and buy food for poultry

loans.name: Fidelino De Jesús

texts.es: El señor Fidelino a sus 39 años de edad es padre de un hijo de nueve años. Por varios años, el señor Fidelino se dedicó a las labores del campo, pero con el fin de buscar mayor estabilidad económica se decidió hace dos años a la venta de mercancía tal como ropa para dama y caballero y artículos para el hogar. El señor Fidelino visita alrededor de siete veredas y el casco urbano del municipio donde vive. El señor Fidelino ha sacado adelante a su familia gracias a este negocio. El señor Fidelino requiere de la compra de surtido con el fin de suplir los pedidos que ya tiene por motivo de fin de año, aumentar sus ventas, mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia y cumplir su sueño de ampliar más su mercado, conseguir más clientes y visitar otros municipios de Antioquia.
texts.en:
Sr. Fidelino is 39 years old and the father of a nine-year-old son. For several years he worked as a farm laborer, but he wanted in the end to have greater financial stability. Two years ago he decided to sell merchandise, such as men’s and women’s clothing and household goods. Sr. Fidelino travels to approximately seven neighborhoods and the urban section of the town where he lives. Thanks to this business, he is able to help his family get ahead.

Sr. Fidelino wants to buy inventory so that he can complete the orders he has received for the year-end season. This will increase his sales, improve his family’s quality of life, and fulfill his dream of expanding his market. As a result, he will be able to acquire more customers and visit other towns in Antioquia.

loans.use: to buy men's and women's clothing.

loans.name: Tursunay

texts.ru:
Турсунай 58 лет, замужем. Турсунай, муж Шахабидин и сын занимаются полеводством и выращиванием хлопка, но так как эта работа носит сезонный характер,  в поисках дополнительного источника дохода для своей семьи, в 2000 году Турсунай начала свой бизнес в торговле одеждой на рынке. Благодаря настойчивости  и упорному труду,  Турсунай сумела развить свой бизнес  с ежемесячным доходом  около 15,000 сом (KGS) и оборотными средствами в сумме 80,000 сом (KGS).  
В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Турсунай обратилась  в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на расширение ассортимента.  Доходы от кредита Турсунай планирует вложить в  расширение торгового места, и в перспективе – начать параллельно разводить скот.
texts.en:
Tursunay is 58 years old and married.  Tursunay, her husband Shakhabidin, and her son grow cotton.  But because this work is of a seasonal nature, and in search of supplemental income for her family, in 2000 Tursunay began her own business selling clothes at the market.  Thanks to her persistence and hard work, she was able to develop her business which now has a monthly income of about 15,000 som (KGS) and working assets of 80,000 som (KGS).  

With the goal of further developing her business, Tursunay turned to Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan of 100,000 som (KGS) to widen her assortment of goods.  Tursunay plans to invest the income from her loan in enlarging her sales stall and, in the future, to begin breeding cattle as well.

loans.use: to broaden her assortment of goods.

loans.name: Exaltacion

texts.en:
This is Exaltacion, 62, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Jose and is the mother of six children, all of whom are already working. At this time she is working hard to be able to support their daily expenses.

Exaltacion has operated a rug-making business for almost six years. She mainly offers rugs from those round palm-sized ones to the much larger doormats, and other crafts that most rug-makers come up with every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney (a small bus) down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Exaltacion dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and she also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 
 
* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw materials like fabric and thread needed in her business

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
Romeo is 30 years old and is a married man with 3 children. He works as a farmer in Trinidad, Bohol. Romeo has been growing and selling rice for 5 years. Each month, he earns 4,000 PHP doing this farming. Romeo works hard to provide for his family and send his children to school. 

Romeo is requesting a loan to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers. He hopes to own a bigger farm in the future.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Gloria Yaneth

texts.es: La señora Gloria a sus 34 años de edad es madre de tres hijos de 18, 14, y 7 años de edad. La señora Gloria tiene su propio negocio de venta de mercancía desde hace siete años, el cual le brinda los recursos necesarios para los gastos de su hogar.  La mercancía es vendida a sus amigos, familiares y vecinos. La señora Gloria requiere de la compra de surtido para su negocio tal como tennis con el fin de poder aumentar sus ingresos en la temporada de fin de año y así mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia y cumplir su sueño tener su propio almacén de venta de zapatos y ropa para toda la familia.
texts.en:
Sra. Gloria is 34 years old and the mother of three children (ages 18, 14, and 7). She has her own business in which she has sold merchandise for the past seven years. This business provides the necessary income to pay for the household expenses. Gloria sells merchandise to her friends, relatives, and neighbors.

She is requesting a loan in order to restock her business with merchandise, such as tennis shoes, so that she can increase her sales during the year-end season and improve her family’s quality of life. Gloria will also be able to fulfill her dream of having her own store where she can sell shoes and clothes for the entire family.

loans.use: to buy shoes and clothing for women, men, and children.

loans.name: Frangky

texts.en:
Frangky is a 33-year-old widower who is living with his son, Farel, four years old.  Frangky owns a broiler business. He learnt how to run the business from his father. His family is known as broiler entrepreneurs in the village. Frangky was entrusted to continue the business after his father died. He has been running the business for 10 years  
 
Six months ago, Frangky suffered losses as hundreds of chickens died. But this situation did not stop him to keep running the business. Frangky is planning to purchase 5 boxes of chicks, feed, vaccines and vitamins. Therefore, he is seeking a loan amounting to IDR 8,000,000 from TLM. Frangky is hoping that TLM will assist him in improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase 5 boxes of chicks, feed, vaccines, and vitamins.

loans.name: Dinh's Group

texts.en:
Dinh is 45 years old. She has one child who is going to university. She has a shop. She is a tailor. She has had this job for 3 years. She has a monthly income of about 2,000,000 Vietnamese dong (VND).

She has participated in SEDA since 2010. She is a member of the Duc Lan cluster. The last time she borrowed 2,016,000 VND and repaid this loan punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 3,360,000 VND to buy cloth for her shop. 

About the other borrower in her group :

Thu is 47 years old. She wants to borrow 7,392,000 VND to buy food for pigs.

loans.use: to buy cloth for her shop

loans.name: Rosa Irene

texts.es: La señora Rosa a sus 45 años de edad es madre de 6 hijos, es una emprendedora quien decide comprarle a un conocido por un bajo precio varios computadores y cabinas para iniciar su propio negocio de cibercafé, en el cual lleva un año. Inicialmente, la señora Rosa no contaba con el conocimiento sobre informática, pero sus hijos le sirvieron de apoyo y profesores mientras la señora Rosa aprendía sobre este tema. La señora Rosa requiere de la compra de un computador que le permita mejorar los servicios en su negocio, incrementar sus ingresos y mejorar la calidad de vida de sus hijos, especialmente del menor de ellos que sufre de cáncer en el colón y a su vez cumplir sus sueños de continuar creciendo en su negocio y ver que su hijo enfermo logre recuperarse totalmente.
texts.en:
Sra. Rosa is a 45-year-old mother of six children. She is an entrepreneur who decided to buy several low-priced computers and work stations so that she could start her own cybercafé. Rosa has been in business for one year. Initially Rosa did not know anything about computers, but her children helped her and taught her while she learned about this subject.

She is requesting a loan in order to buy a computer, which will improve the services she offers in her business. This will increase her earnings and improve the quality of life for her children, especially the youngest one who has colon cancer. In time, she hopes to fulfill her dreams of continuing to grow her business and seeing her son make a complete recovery.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Vekhy

texts.en:
Vekhy is a 43-year-old man, married to Yanse, 40 years old. They have six children namely: Jekson, 21, a high school graduate; Jeklin, 13; Yeni, 11 both attending junior high school; Jessy, 9; Julia, 7, attending elementary school and George, 5, at kindergarten.

Vekhy owns a sofa/couch repair business; it is located about five kilometers from his house. Vekhy operates the business from 9 am to 7 pm; sometimes he has to work overnight to complete an order on time. Vekhy does not employ an assistant, and he is very busy lately since many orders should be completed before Christmas.
 
Currently Vekhy needs a compressor and an air stapler tool to support the business. He is requesting a loan of IDR 4,000,000 from TLM. He is hoping that TLM will approve the loan application very soon.

loans.use: to purchase a compressor and an air stapler tool.

loans.name: Vu

texts.en:
Vu is 44 years old. She is a member of the Duc Lan cluster. She has two children. Not only does she grow rice but she also breeds poultry. She has raised chickens for three years.

She has participated in SEDA since 2008. The last time she borrowed 8,288,000 Vietnamese dong (VND). This is the 5th time she borrowed money from SEDA. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 9,184,000 VND to buy food for pigs.

loans.use: to buy food for pigs

loans.name: Aveave

texts.en:
Aveave, a 53-year-old married mother of five, plants and harvests taro for sale. With six years of experience in this business, Aveave is requesting her first loan for WST $1000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve/expand the enterprise.

In 2011, Aveave joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Because they lack collateral, most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks.

SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is), and these are averaged for the ""overall social metric score."" For example, a 3 out of 3 on ""level of education"" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

About SPBD In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.

loans.name: Yuri Alexandra

texts.es: La señora Yuri a sus 23 años de edad es una madre soltera de un bebe de un año de nacido, quien tiene cuatro años de experiencia dedicada a los tratamientos faciales y corporales en spas de la ciudad de Medellín y el municipio de Amagá ubicado al sur de Antioquia.  La señora Yuri debido a su embarazo se retiro por un tiempo de esta actividad, hasta el dia de hoy, cuando lleva ya ocho meses trabajando independiente realizando trabajos desde su casa y domicilios, lo que le permite estar al cuidado de su bebe. La señora Yuri requiere de la compra de diferentes tipos de tratamientos con los cuales pueda aumentar su capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio para brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes, generar mayores ingresos y cumplir su sueño de brindar una excelente calidad de vida a su hijo y tener su propio local.
texts.en:
Sra. Yuri is 23 years old and a single mother with a one-year-old baby. She has four years of experience selling facial and body treatments to spas in the city of Medellín and the town of Amagá, which is south of Antioquia. Sra. Yuri stopped working for awhile after she became pregnant. She resumed her business eight months ago and currently works independently from home, which allows her to take care of her baby.

Sra. Yuri is requesting a loan in order to buy different types of treatments, which will increase her operating capital and restock her business so that she can better serve her customers. As a result, she will generate more income and fulfill her dream of providing an excellent quality of life for her child and opening her own store.

loans.use: to buy hair, body, and facial treatments.

loans.name: Maliana

texts.en:
Maliana is 28 years old and married with two children.

Maliana owns and operates a business selling baked goods in the local community. She has one year of experience in this business. Maliana needs a loan of WST 1,000 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2011, Maliana joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Maliana's first loan with SPBD. 

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the ""overall social metric score.""  For example, a 3 out of 3 on ""level of education"" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale.

loans.name: Rasela

texts.en:
Rasela is 45 years old and married with eight children.

Rasela owns and operates a business selling fried foods in the local community. She has one year of experience in this business. Rasela needs a loan of WST 1,000 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2011, Rasela joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Rasela's first loan with SPBD. 

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score." For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products for sale.

loans.name: Mamerto

texts.en:
Despite the hardships of farming Mamerto believes that he will lift their status of living and provide for the needs of his family. He is 49-years-old and has been ten years in this business. He has been blessed with four children and he wants to educate them all to become successful men someday.

He is working hard and strives harder to yield a better income to satisfy their needs and provide his children an education. But due to the high cost of school fees and food costs every day, he is not able to save for the operation of his farming business. For this reason, he is asking for a loan amount of P20,000 to purchase farm inputs such as corn seeds, fertilizers and pesticides used in improving his business. He hopes to develop his business to boost his family’s status of living.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as corn seeds, fertilizers and pesticides used in improving his business.

loans.name: Sosefina

texts.en:
Sosefina is married and 26 years old with four children.

Sosefina owns and operates a business selling ice-cake and popcorn. She has many years of experience in this business. Sosefina needs a loan of WST 2,400 to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 200 talas or $83 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

In 2007, Sosefina joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Sosefina's fourth loan with SPBD. 

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score." For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  "

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
This is Evangeline, 57, a resident of in Dasmariñas Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Josefino, her business partner and father to their children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Evangeline makes a living by operating a Xerox copy machine and selling school supplies other merchandize. She has been in this business for seven years and is very knowledgeable about the preferences of her customers, most of whom are students and young people who buy her products. She earns a minimum of 1,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her to continue operating her business, she is applying for a loan of PHP 19,000. She will be using the money to buy more school supplies and merchandise that she will sell. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Evangeline dreams of having a successful business over the years. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners which gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional school supplies and other merchandise that she will sell in her business.

loans.name: Solaua

texts.en:
Solaua is 59 years old and has six children.

Solaua owns and operates a business planting and harvesting bananas for sale. She has many years of experience in this business. Solaua needs a loan of WST 1,250 to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 250 talas or $104 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Solaua joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Solaua's fourth loan with SPBD. 

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score." For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  PBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies and equipment.

loans.name: Nerissa

texts.en:
This is Nerissa, 47, a resident of Dasmariñas Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Ulysses, a local Official, and is a mother to their children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Nerissa operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighbourhood customers. It is the place to go to buy a container of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Nerissa earns money by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 2,000 in sales every day.

To help her to continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Nerissa hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to send her children to college. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products that she sells in her business.

loans.name: Jelia

texts.en:
Jelia is 25 years old and a single mother of a five-year-old child. To earn a living, she runs a retail shop. She has been in the business for two years and has employed one person. Previously, she used to sell clothes for a living. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to access business loans.  This has helped her to grow her business.

Jelia has requested for a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy a shaving machine and a hair drier.

loans.use: To buy a shaving machine and a hair drier.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom is a 50-year-old married mother with five children, four of whom are dependents working on her plantation. She is a farmer in a flat area of the Ponhea Krek district, where crop farming is common. She supplements her income by growing cassava. Mom has been in this business for 30 years. With her current business, she earns around 30 U.S. dollars per day and can save less than 5 U.S. dollars per day. 

Having been with VisionFund since 2010, Mom has regular income and now is applying for her second loan with VisionFund. She wants to buy cassava seedlings for her plantation. With this loan, she hopes to increase her yield of cassava so as to earn more income to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy cassava seedlings for her farm.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Solagratia

texts.en:
Solagratia, a 34-year-old man, is married to Marleni, a 29-year-old lady. They are blessed with four children: Patrich, 9; Marna, 6; Gavrilla, 5, attending Elementary School, and Lionel, 1 month.  

Solagratia raises catfish; this business was initiated in 2008. He utilized the land next to his house to develop two artificial reservoirs, constructed out of wood and zinc with tarpaulin inside to keep the water in.  

Currently, Solagratia has many customers. They usually come to his business place and select the catfish directly. Solagratia desires to raise more catfish but he does not have money to do so. Fortunately, he heard about TLM and would like to request a loan of IDR 4,500,000. 

Solagratia is hoping that he can improve the business with the loan from TLM.

loans.use: to purchase small fish to raise.

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en: Aged 47, Sambath is married with five children, two of whom are dependents and still in school. Rice farming has been a main income source for her family for 20 years, supplemented with a cassava plantation. With her current business, Sambath earns around 20 US dollars per day to feed her big family and can save around 5 US dollars per day after family expenses. This is Sambath’s first loan with VisionFund. She is now requesting a loan to renovate a new house for her family. She hopes that this loan will enable her to have a decent, new house to live in.

loans.use: to renovate a new house to live in

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Chenjeni Farmers Group

texts.en:
Ephynex is the facilitator of the Chenjeni Farmers group. Ephynex and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Ephynex takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Ephynex had a good maize yield, harvesting 11 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Ephynex was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Ephynex and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Ephynex will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Chenjeni Farmers group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel used his previous loan of 40, 000 Kenya shillings to buy welding rods and metals. With the additional stock of raw materials, he has managed to make more metallic doors and window frames.  This has allowed him to attract more customers. His desire is to expand his business and grow his clientele.

Daniel has requested another loan of 80, 000 Kenya shillings to buy more raw material such as metal.

loans.use: to buy metal.

loans.name: Ramilo

texts.en:
Ramilo is 34-years-old and has been involved in rice farming as a source of income for almost 10 years now. His family relies on his net income per harvest season. He owns a hectare rice field and half-hectare plot of land where he grows vegetables too. He is a very industrious man and his family inspires him to work hard. He plants rice and harvests it to sell to traders. 

He wants to improve his harvest but it requires a larger capital which he lacks financially. He is now requesting a loan of P30,000 to buy 4 liters of herbicides and insecticides to use in farming. This will improve his crops and enable him to generate more profits for the education of his three children. His children are still in elementary grades.

In the future, Ramilo would like to make consistent profits for the improvement of their living condition.

loans.use: to buy 4 liters of herbicides and insecticides to use in farming.

loans.name: Leat

texts.en: Leat, 46, is married with five children who are dependents and only one child is still in school. Rice farming has been a main income source for her family for 32 years, supplemented with pig raising. Sometimes, she works for others to gain additional income. With her current income, Leat earns more than 10 US dollars per day to feed her big family and can save less than 5 US dollars per day after family expenses. This is Leat’s first loan with VisionFund. Now requesting a loan, she will use this loan to renovate a new house for her family. With this loan, she hopes to have a decent, new house to live in.

loans.use: To renovate a new house to live in

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Edison

texts.en:
Edison is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in Uganda. For the past five years, Edison has been working hard to manage his bar, which sells alcoholic beverages and soft drinks. 

To help expand his business, Edison has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more crates of beer and soft drinks, and will help Edison to generate greater profits and improve his family's standard of living. Edison hopes that in the future he will be able to open up a large bar. 

Edison is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Edison who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer and soft drinks

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael is 29 years old, married and blessed with one child. He is a simple farmer who needs to earn more income to satisfy the needs and support the education of his child. He is asking for a loan of P20,000 to buy corn seeds, fertilizers and pesticides. These would be a great help in increasing his opportunity to earn a better income. He believes that when the loan is accompanied by hard work, he will develop his business and satisfy the needs of his family.

loans.use: to buy corn seeds, fertilizers and pesticides.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 33 years old and married to David. They do not have children yet. Grace deals with scrap metal.  She has been in this business for the last ten years and earns a monthly profit of KES. 30,000. 
Grace has applied for her third loan of  KES.100,000 from KADET LTD. She plans to use the loan amount to buy more scrap metal for sale.

Grace will save the anticipated profits and plow them back into her business. She hopes to grow her business and be financially stable.

loans.use: To add more stock of scrap metal for sale

loans.name: Resty

texts.en:
Resty is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in Uganda. For the past six years, Resty has been working hard to manage her restaurant and bar, which prepares hot meals for customers and offers beer and soft drinks. 

To help expand her business, Resty has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more ingredients for food and more crates of beer and soda. This will help Resty to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Resty hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another bar. 

Resty is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Resty who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients for food and more crates of beer and soda

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 28 years old and married to Vivian.They have two children. He buys and sells cereals to earn a living and besides that, he also sells a grocery inclusive of fruits. He earns an income of Kshs.10,000 every month and he has been in this business for a period of one year now. 

He has applied for a loan of Kshs. 20,000 which he will use to buy more cereals for sale. This is his first loan from KADET LTD and he hopes to pay it well without delays.

His dreams for the future business and his family is to be the leading distributor of goods in the whole district.

loans.use: to buy more stock of  cerals and fruits for sale
