She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Sidoeun's Group

texts.en:
Sidoeun, a 35-year-old married mother with two children who are dependents and still in school.  She lives in a village in the Ponhea Krek district and grows cassava plants, supplementing her income by running a small business in the front yard selling biscuits, cakes etc and also raising pigs to gain additional income. She has been with this business for more than 1 year. With her current business, she earns less than 7 US dollars per day. Sidoeun leads of a group of four female members. 

This is Sidoeun's group’s first loan with VisionFund. Now she is requesting a loan to buy cassava seedlings for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to grow more cassava and earn more income to make a living better and also keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy cassava seedlings for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is 40 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in Uganda. She is married and has five children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past three years, Margret has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells various types of food. 

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more ingredients for her dishes, and will help Margret to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Margret hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another business. 

Margret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Margret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients for the food she sells at her restaurant.

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en:
Faridah is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past five years, Faridah has been working hard to manage her bar, which sells different kinds of beers and sodas. 

To help expand her business, Faridah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more crates of beer and soda, and will help Faridah to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Faridah hopes that in the future she will be able to start another business. 

Faridah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Faridah, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer and soda for resale in her pub.

loans.name: Luafulufa

texts.en:
Luafulufa is 38 years of age and married, with five children.  She owns and operates a business venture, planting and harvesting bananas for sale.  She has three years of experience in this business.  Luafulufa needs a loan of WST 1500 to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 200 talas or US $83 per week) to improve and expand her business.

Luafulufa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Luafulufa 's third loan with SPBD. 


*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD: 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives.

loans.name: Kulumbeni Farmers Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Kulumbeni Farmers Group in Western Kenya! Agnes is the facilitator of the Kalumbeni Farmers group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Agnes takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Agnes had a good maize yield harvesting 26 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Agnes was only able to harvest 10 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Agnes  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Agnes will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Kalumbeni Farmers group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy is 42 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past five years, Teddy has been working hard to manage her beauty shop, which sells various kinds of cosmetics. 

To help expand her business, Teddy has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cosmetics products for resale, and will help Teddy to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Teddy hopes that in the future she will be able to start up another business. 

Teddy is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Teddy who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetics products for resale.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is a 47-year-old farmer married to Mumbua. They have three children, aged 18, 13 and nine years old. Edward has been running his vegetable farm for about 10 years, earning an income of approximately 12,800 Kenyan shillings per month. 

This is his first loan from KADET LTD, after being introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer. He will use the loan to buy seedlings and to pay workers and for the machines which will be involved in tilling the land before planting.  

He hopes to expand his farm and to diversify his business, both during and outside of the growing season. He hopes to obtain a big pump to supply water to the farm when the rains fail. He is a hardworking person who is determined and believes in himself.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and to pay workers and use of machines which will be used to till the land.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is 45 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in Uganda. She has lost her husband and is now raising four children by herself. For the past ten years, Margret has been working hard to manage her produce stand in the local market. 

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more tomatoes and other vegetables for resale, and it will help Margret to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Margret hopes that in the future she will be able to develop her side business (charcoal) and become a major supplier. 

Margret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Margret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Ignatius

texts.en:
Ignatius is 59 years old, married, and the father of three children. He runs a matatu (shared taxi) business in Bombolulu, Mombasa. His business has been in operation for the last 20 years, and it is doing well.

Ignatius is requesting his second loan from KADET LTD. He will use the loan to refurbish his matatu to make more trips to and from his service area. The additional profits will enable him to acquire a second matatu, thus expanding his business.

With the anticipated profits, he plans to repay his KADET loan. Ignatius hopes to expand his business into a transport company in the future and have a happy family.

loans.use: to refurbish his matatu in order to make more trips.

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past three years, Annet has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells traditional Ugandan food to local customers. 

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more ingredients for her dishes, and it will help Annet to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Annet hopes that in the future she will be able to start up another business. 

Annet is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Annet who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients for her dishes.

loans.name: Kimleav's Group

texts.en:
A 31-year-old married mother, Kimleav lives in a village within Ponhea Krek district. She has three dependent children, two of whom are in school while the third is too young to attend school. 

Kimleav has been raising pigs for six years, supplementing her income by planting cassava. With her current business, she earns more than 5 US dollars per day. Kimleav has been with VisionFund since 2010, and she leads of a group of five female members. She is requesting a loan of US$225 to buy piglets and feed for her pigs. With the loan, she hopes to produce more fat and healthy pigs in order to increase her income, provide a better living for her family, and keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed to increase her business.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in Uganda. She is married and has four children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past five years, Teopista has been working hard to manage her grocery store, which sells fish, tomatoes, and onions. 

To help expand her business, Teopista has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fish and produce for resale, and it will help Teopista to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Teopista hopes that in the future she will be able to start another business. 

Teopista is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Teopista who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more fish and produce for resale.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is 30 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past two years, Samson has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells food and household supplies to local customers. 

To help expand his business, Samson has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food products for resale, and it will help Samson to generate greater profits and improve his family's welfare. Samson hopes that in the future he will be able to start up other businesses. 

Samson is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Samson who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more food products for resale.

loans.name: Johnsen

texts.en:
Johnsen is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kibuli in Uganda. He is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past three years, Johnsen has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells food and household supplies to local customers.

To help expand his business, Johnsen has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sugar, salt, and cooking oil for resale, and it will help Johnsen to generate greater profits and improve his family's welfare. Johnsen hopes that in the future he will be able to construct more rental houses for extra income. 

Johnsen is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Johnsen who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Maiva

texts.en:
Maiva is 40 years old and lives in the town of Gaba in Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past ten years, Maiva has been working hard to manage her hardware store, which sells building supplies like piping.

To help expand her business, Maiva has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more construction supplies for resale, and it will help Maiva to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Maiva hopes that in the future she will be able to establish another business. 

Maiva is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Maiva who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more construction supplies for resale.

loans.name: Moul

texts.en:
Moul is 41 years old and a responsible mother of four children. She lives, together with her family, in Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia. She is a local farmer, as are other villagers. Besides agriculture, Moul buys and resells rice from place to place in order to earn a greater profit. She usually earns an average income of $6.50 per day. This business provides her a satisfactory income and she also enjoys doing her job. 

It is now harvesting season for rice farmers and so it is a good time for Moul to start stocking up on rice for resale again. However, she has insufficient capital to invest in this project. That is why Moul is seeking the support of Kiva’s lenders to support her business.

loans.use: to buy a stock of rice for future sale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 34 years old and married with two children aged five and eight. She sells natural medicines and health products to earn a living. She has been in the business for one year. She also farms to supplement her income. 
Rose hopes to grow her business, opening other outlets and employing more people. 
Rose is a new member of Faulu Kenya and has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy natural medicines.

loans.use: To buy natural medicine.

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en:
Sylivia is 40 years old and lives in the town of Gaba in Uganda. She is married and has five children, four of whom are currently in school. For the past ten years, Sylivia has been working hard to manage her business, which sells engine oil retail and wholesale. 

To help expand her business, Sylivia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more oil for resale, and will help Sylivia to generate greater profits and cater to her family's basic needs. Sylivia hopes that in the future she will be able to establish another branch of her business. 

Sylivia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sylivia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more oil for resale.

loans.name: Miyoke A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Miyoke A Group in Western Kenya! Jane is the facilitator of the Miyoke A group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Jane takes care of two children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Jane had a very good maize yield harvesting 13 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jane was only able to harvest 7 1/2 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jane and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Jane will educate her children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Miyoke A group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Jane with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

In the recent 2011 season, Sarah had a good maize yield, harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Sarah was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Sarah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Sarah will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Utamaduni group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.
